div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
DISSOLUTION IMMINENT.
MEETING OF CABINET.
LIBERAL PROGRAMME.
div.p: (Gazette’s Special Service.)
Neither party generally nor Mr. Chamberlain has responded to Mr. Balfour's appeal. The “Times” foreshadows an immediate dissolution.

Considerable interest has been caused in political circles by strong hints, both in the "Times” and “Daily Telegraph," that Mr. Balfour should, in view of Mr. Chamberlain's attitude, take an early opportunity for resigning. The Liberals would then form a Government, and Parliament would be dissol- ved alter a brief meeting.

A meeting of the Cabinet will be held to- morrow. Rumour anticipates that the result will be the first step towards resignation, which today is the absorbing topic. The Liberal newspapers declare that Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman will refuse to form a Cabinet under the present circumstances, and will insist on dissolution. (Reuter)

div.head: MACEDONIAN CRISIS.
THE SULTAN'S ORDERS.
div.p: The Sultan has sent Admiral Husni to the Dardanelles. It is stated that he bears instruc- tions to the commander of the forts in view of the contingency of an international blockade. Instruction have also been sent to the gover- nors of Mityleno and other islands. (Reuter)
The ships of the Powers that are to take part in the naval demonstration against Tur- key have arrived at tho Pireus. (Havas)

div.head: NEW JAPANESE LOAN.
DIVISION AMONG CAPITALS.
div.p: Twenty-five millions of the Japanese Loan have been issued at ninety. Paris takes twelve millions, London six and a half millions, New York three and a quarter, and Berlin three and a quarter millions. (Reuter)

div.head: KING HAKON.
DEPARTURE FROM COPENHAGEN.
div.p: The city is beflagged and thronged to-day in honor of the departure of King Hakon and Queen Maud for Christiania. Both were deeply moved by the farewell King Christian and the Royal family on the quay and the forts salut- ed as the royal yacht Dannebrog hoisted the royal flag of Norway and steamed out, escorted by the flotilla of warships, which Prince Henry of Prussia joined at Elsimore. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN RAILWAYS.
WORKING NORMALLY AGAIN.
div.p: The circulation of trains throughout Russia has become normal again. (Havas)

div.head: THE MOROCCO CONFERENCE.
FRANCE’S REPRESENTATIVE.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Tourists.
The British steam yacht Argonant arrived at Alexandria to-day from Port Said.
The Brindisi Mail.
The Brindisi mail will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
Legislative Council.
The Legislative Council will meet on December 2, to study the Budget for 1906.
Wakfs Administration.
Maitre Saint-Plancat has been appointed counsel to the Wakfs Administration.
Gambling Hell Raid.
The Cairo police raided a gambling hell in the Wagh el-Birket quarter of Cairo on Wed- nesday night.
Fatal Accident.
A native boy of 3 years was run over and killed yesterday by a cart in the Labbane quarter. The driver was arrested.
Suez Canal.

Fourteen vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst., of which 8 wore British, 3 German, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Russian. The total receipts from the 1st to the 20th inst. were frs. 6,884,866.08.
Credit Lyonnais.
M. Adon, sub manager of the Credit Lyon- nais at Cairo, has been appointed to succeed M. Petcovich, as sub-manager of the Alex- andria branch of the bank. M. Lascaris will succeed M. Adon at Cairo.
Fatira Company.

An application has been made to the Com- mittee of the London Stock Exchange to appoint a special settling day in—Fatira (Egypt) Exploring Company, Limited, 10,007 shares of £1 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 7 and 65,008 to 75.007.
Union Fonciere.

Application his been made to the Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to— L’Union Fonciere D'Egypte, share warrants to bearer for 100,000 shares of £5 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 100000.
Copts and the Railways.

“Al Lewa” publishes an article three col- umns in length urging the reconstituted Board of tho Railway Administration to employ Mos- lems and Copts according to the numerical proportion they respective’y bear to the popu- lation, i.e., 95 per cent. Moslems and 5 per cent Copts.
Tuberculosis in Egypt.

The league, which was founded at Alexandria some years ago to combat the ravages of tubercolusis in Egypt, has published its financial statement for the twelve months up to June 30. During the year P.T. 59,439 1 was collected, and after all expenses are deducted, there remains a balance of P.T. 14,637 on the year’s working.
Cairo Season.

The Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be reopened on Monday, the 27th inst. The management had to open a few days earlier than was intended owing to there being a number of families already waiting in the different hotels fo move to the Savoy. They will there- fore have numerous guests right from the beginning. The Savoy is confident of a very good season.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE TO EGYPT.
A MISAPPREHENSION.
div.p: Some misunderstanding appears to have arisen as to tho recent petition in favor of placing Egypt on the same footing as the component parts of the British Empire in respect to penny postage. For example, a Cairo French contemporary commented on the petition in the following terms: -

La petition sinsi presentee no laisse pas d’etre gaie. Faut-il que les signataires aient onblie que les postes sont soumises a une convention internationale, et que s’il appar- tient au gouvernement égyptien de donner la preference aux anglais pour le service dans ses administrations, il ne peut favoriser l'Angle- terre d’nne taxe postale speciale.

Qu’on demande la reduction pour tous les pays, cela n’aurait rien que de louable, et tout le monde applaudirait au project. Mais il serait peu charitable d’insister davantage sur l’inco- herence de la démarche des pétitionnaires. D’ailleurs S. E. Saba pacha, cousulte a ce anjet, leur a fait entendre qu’il approuverait pleinement la reduction a un penny de la taxe postale, pour tous les pays.

These opinions are erroneous, for in virtue of the Washington Convention Egypt can agree to accept lower postal rates, but is prohibited from increasing these rates. Thus it would be quite feasible for Egypt to enter into conven- tion on this subject with the British Govern- ment.

div.head: POST CARD FACILITIES.
div.p: The Egyptian postal authorities have been informed that the English Post Office bas decided in principle to accept the receipt of postcards from all other countries with half of the address side allotted for correspondence. No date has, however, yet been given as to when this new regulation will come into force.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY, LTD.
div.p: The report of the New Egyptian Company, Limited, has just been issued. A profit of £45,000 has been realised and a dividend of 2s.6d. per share or 12.5%, has been declared. The assets of the company, excluding lands reclaimed in the bed of the Nile, by virtue of its concassion from the Egyptian Government, show an appreciation of £100,000.

div.head: BANK OF ROME.
div.p: The question of establishing a branch of the Bank of Rome at Cairo is under discussion. M. Pacelli, chairman of the board of directors, and M. Benucci, managing director of the bank, are proceeding to Cairo for this purpose.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: H H. the Khedive has conferred a number of decorations and grades on the officials of the Daira Sinieh Administration on the occasion of its final liquidation. Ahmed Balig Pasha, Director General, has received the Grand Cordon (1st class) of the Order of the Medjidieh, and Birch Pasha, Inspector General, the grade of Grand Officer (2nd class) of the same Order. The grade of Commander (3rd class) of the Order of the Osmanieh has been conferred on Fonrneron Bey, chief engineer, and M. Gaston Privat, advocate. Ahmed Rifaat Pasha, Sub- Inspector-General, has been raised to the rank of Mirmiran.
His Highness has also conferred the grade of Officer (4th class) of the Order of the Med- jidieh on Mr. C. T. Currelly, of the Egypt Exploration Fund.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The cashier of the Anglo-Egyptian Spinning and Weaving Company was committed for trial yesterday at the British Consular Court, Alex- andria. He will be tried for embezzlement at the forthcoming session of the Supreme Con- sular Court.

div.head: AMERICAN CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The trial of M. Vonreky, an American citizen of Hellenic extraction, who follows the calling of a broker at Alexandria, took place yesterday afternoon at the American Con- sular Agency before the Hon. Mr. Iddings, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul- General. The accused was charged with assaulting a Greek coffee-house keeper of Alexandra by throwing him out of bis office. The case was eventually settled by a compre- mise, the plaintiff agreeing to accept P.T. 100 from the defendant.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah arrived at Li- verpool yesterday afternoon.
The Moss liner Seti sailed this morning for Manchester via Malts, with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 7,030 bales cotton.
The Conard S.S. Brescia sailed direct for Liverpool yesterday afternoon with a fall cargo including 6,672 bales cotton.
The S.S. Spartan Prince, from Manchester, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta yesterday, and is due at Alexandria on Monday.

div.head: CAIRO DOG REGULATLONS.
HINTS TO OWNERS
div.p: On the 1st proximo the decree concerning the measures to be adopted in Cairo in the case of rabies will come into force.

Kennels for 50 dogs have now been estab- lished at the infirmary of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Boulac. All stray dogs of every description will be arrested by the police and taken to these kennels.
There is no registration for dogs, nor do the authorities supply medals (metal plaques) for same, but proprietors should see that they wear a collar or medal, bearing their name and address.
A dog found by the police will be kept a period of seven days pending claim. After the seventh day, it will be disposed of if unclaimed.

In the event of a dog being lost; the pro- prietor can visit the kennels, and should the dog be there, application should be made to the Traffic Office, Gonvernorat, for same to be handed over after payment for keep.

ShouId a case of rabies or suspected rabies occur in any locality, an arrete will at once be published, allowing three days from date of publication for all dogs to be muzzled or led on leash, or both. Owners of dogs are there- fore, advised to procure muzzles and leashes in case of accident.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
SEVERO TORELLI.
div.p: Severo Torelli is one of those dramas in which declamation and humanity alike are extended to their limit. Fine and impassioned in its phrasing, and yet at the due moment condescending to exactly expressed familiarity, it should be a sure test, and crucial, for actors. The play presents tyrants, crime, oaths, to break which is to break the chains of Heaven, all, in a word, that we know of 15th-century Italy. As we have intimated, the verse has not that marble, and statuesque rigidity which needs unduly phenomenal acting to transform it from literature to life. We saw it on Wed- nesday night played by a caste who are versed in all the essentials of the highest French drama. A criticism is somewhat difficult. One has to admit that attention was concentrated wholly on the four chief "stars.” The others never seemed to break away from the school and tradition and rhythm. Mile Jeanne Delvair and M. Lambert pere were undoubtedly the best for interpretation and nataral effective "human” acting, but yet we cannot be sure that M. Lambert fils did not reach the highest point of all, though he allowed himself at mo- ments to be carried away by conventional and exaggerated trenzy, and indulged in the vocal crescendos and the looks of horror which must mar the illusion he so nearly maintained. But for the rest he had intonations, sadden changes of manner, gestures that were reality itself, car trying all the conviction that is in that really great drama; and we must admit again, that the other parts could not give occasion for such variety and scope. Donna Pia is a woman, and through Mile Delvair, a heroic woman, keeping, then announcing, and at last greatly avenging her twenty years’ secret; but we need not discuss it—all women are potentially what we call “actresses,” men have a harder task, as their emotions are usually more, separate from their life. For the rest, it was all of interest, well-staged, and with no inconsistencies or faults, the play is certainly a play to read and to see as it was given us on Wednesday. And what greater respect can we show to its interpreters than by criticizing so far as we may, from a psychological point of view, instead of giving the usual list of names with a sentence or two tasked on to each.
We cannot but recommend all who care for French drama to profit by the remaining per- formances of this company in Cario.
